moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3
comment: Since White hasn't yet "declared" where Pd2 will be advanced it's not yet clear whether Bf1 will move to g2 (to complement Pc4) or, after d2-d4, go to d3 where it might threaten Black's king-side. Black's next is an ordinary good development move which happens to impede d2-d4 and might be used later ( by ...e5-e4) to fight White's light square bishop. Naturally Black has various plans at his disposal. This is just one. White won't get much of a clue about Black's intentions, so he has to decide what kind of position he wants and go for it.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5
comment: Kasparov has played the King's Indian Defense extensively, but not recently. He's also played the Gruenfeld Defense, but 2...d5 isn't considered all that good, so he finds another choice.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4
comment: This certainly weakens the c5-f2 diagonal and makes it less possible to utilize Bf1 offensively, unless he can also achieve d2-d4 without his position falling apart.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4
comment: Kasparov keeps the pressure on. This is usually intended to get rid of Nc3, so Black won't have to worry about Nc3-d5. However, in this position it threatens to undermine Pe4. That causes White to postpone d2-d4.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3
comment: He seems intent on limiting Bc8, but in so doing sets up his own position as a target. It's already getting difficult to find a great plan for White. Expanding on the queen-side by a2-a3 would have to be prefaced with Bc1-d2 and Black could generate some king-side offense before that expansion ever becomes a threat. Essentially Black has three minor pieces ready to fight on the king-side (Nc6, Bc8, Nf6) , whereas White has two (Nf3 and Bc1) .

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7
comment: He's apparently decided he can't play on the wing and must fight in the center with ...c7-c6, ...d6-d5, but to do that he has to reorganize a bit.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3
comment: White will have use of the open file, but in an endgame, or late middle-game, his pawns might be targets. On the king-side White's pieces are pretty well situated to meet the oncoming attack, but can do nothing aggressive.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8
comment: This seems to indicate Kasparov is considering ...d6-d5, but one would think opening the center could only be good for White's bishops.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2
comment: Black probably counted on meeting Bc1-g5 with ...Nf6-h5-f4 with pressure on Ph3. But, Kh2 provides Ph3 extra support, so ...Nf6-h5 is immediately met by g2-g3, leaving Nh5 stranded. So, Bc1-g5 should be prevented.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6
comment: Kasparov is making useful moves, but without committing to a specific plan of offense. Perhaps there isn't one and he's just playing an equal position, in hopes his opponent will allow things to slip a bit.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3
comment: This might appear to weaken Nf3, but with Bf1-g2 he shores up his king's position rather neatly. This is the kind of position he could've had straight away. Instead, it's taken him a few moves to get to this and Black is ahead in advancing a plan.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4
comment: Is White's position well-coordinated or a shambles? Neither I suppose, but Black's looks more robust and capable of handling a few line openings. Earlier I said ...d6-d5 would favor White's bishops, but now it's not so clear. Black's rooks would benefit from the d-file opening and Bc1 looks useless.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5
comment: White leaves the lines closed to keep Black's pieces from raging all over his pawns.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7
comment: Black quickly redistributes his pieces toward the queen-side. But, wasn't he ideally prepared for the ...d6-d5 push beforehand? This seems like overkill or overcaution perhaps.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7
comment: Now the Black rooks don't look so terrific. Only the more-or-less permanent White pawn structure problems seem to justify Black taking this time to maneuver. Of course, if White doesn't take advantage of this moment Black might well jump all over him. Bf1 is blocked. Bc1 is blocked. Nd2 is passive. Re1 is blocked and passive. Only Qb3 & Rb1 are doing something significant.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5
comment: effectively "killing" Nb3 and Bc1!

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6
comment: He leaves square c6 open for the moment, hoping to maneuver a knight through there before Qc6.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8
comment: Apparently Kasparov intends ...Nb8-c6-a5 and possibly ...Qc7-f7 to threaten Pc4. So, Pb6 is a more proper target for White, than invading on the a-file.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4
comment: Opening this second front when he's arguably positionally worse is dangerous.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7
comment: By chasing the bishop onto f7 he prevents ...Qc7-f7. This keeps Pc4 safer. But, it also weakens White's king's safety.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8
comment: Kasparov takes advantage of the newly opened file. With time control nearing this could have a disastrous effect on his opponent's composure. There are many White weaknesses and only a limited number of pieces to defend.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8 38. Bf2 Rh5 39. Nf3 Qc6 40. Qc2 Bxc4
comment: It's hard to change gears and not follow through on a plan. And, in this case, it looks pretty good for Black.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8 38. Bf2 Rh5 39. Nf3 Qc6 40. Qc2 Bxc4 41. Bg2 Nf7
comment: Going toward the king-side isn't necessary now. Kasparov is split between winning on the queen-side and bashing the exposed Kg1 (well at least it was a couple of moves ago) and this fragments his play. Sticking to winning on the queen-side, in this particular game, should be sufficient to win.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8 38. Bf2 Rh5 39. Nf3 Qc6 40. Qc2 Bxc4 41. Bg2 Nf7 42. Qd1 Bb3 43. Nxe5
comment: a very nifty tactical shot!

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8 38. Bf2 Rh5 39. Nf3 Qc6 40. Qc2 Bxc4 41. Bg2 Nf7 42. Qd1 Bb3 43. Nxe5 Bxd1 44. Nxc6+ Nxc6 45. Rxd1 Nxg5
comment: Kasparov has won a pawn, but his attack on Kg1 evaporated and White has the two bishops in a position which is rapidly opening up.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8 38. Bf2 Rh5 39. Nf3 Qc6 40. Qc2 Bxc4 41. Bg2 Nf7 42. Qd1 Bb3 43. Nxe5 Bxd1 44. Nxc6+ Nxc6 45. Rxd1 Nxg5 46. Rb1 Nh3+ 47. Bxh3 Rxh3 48. Rxb6
comment: There goes the extra pawn.

moves: 1. c4 Nf6 2. Nc3 e5 3. Nf3 Nc6 4. e4 Bb4 5. d3 d6 6. h3 O-O 7. Be2 Ne7 8. O-O c6 9. a3 Bxc3 10. bxc3 Ng6 11. Re1 Re8 12. Bf1 Bd7 13. Qb3 Qc8 14. Rb1 b6 15. Kh2 h6 16. g3 Qc7 17. Bg2 Be6 18. Nd2 Rad8 19. a4 d5 20. a5 dxc4 21. axb6 axb6 22. dxc4 Nd7 23. Bf1 Ne7 24. Qc2 Nc8 25. Nb3 c5 26. Be3 Nd6 27. Nd2 Ra8 28. Ra1 f6 29. Ra2 Rxa2 30. Qxa2 Nb8 31. f4 Nc6 32. f5 Bf7 33. g4 Na5 34. h4 Kf8 35. g5 hxg5 36. hxg5 Ke7 37. Kg1 Rh8 38. Bf2 Rh5 39. Nf3 Qc6 40. Qc2 Bxc4 41. Bg2 Nf7 42. Qd1 Bb3 43. Nxe5 Bxd1 44. Nxc6+ Nxc6 45. Rxd1 Nxg5 46. Rb1 Nh3+ 47. Bxh3 Rxh3 48. Rxb6 Kd6 49. Kg2 Rxc3
comment: After 50. Bg3+ Black's Pg7 might well fall, so they call it a draw; though Pc5 is still a threat and one could see Black fighting on. Kasparov was a bit unlucky to have only drawn. Most of the time he'd win that kind of game.
